article_content:
**"One Big Beautiful Bill" a symbolic legislative proposal**

A proposed bill known as the "One Big Beautiful Bill Act" (H.R. 1) is listed in the U.S. Congress database under House Bill No. 1, but no official legislative action—such as committee referral, floor debate, or passage—is currently associated with it in the 119th Congress. The bill has no verified text or detailed provisions publicly available, and no cosponsors have been identified. 

Rep. Jodey C. Arrington (R-TX-19) is listed as the sponsor, while no cosponsors are recorded. The bill is not currently under consideration in any committee or chamber, and there are no public records of hearings held on H.R. 1 or related measures such as H.R. 1403 or H.R. 1151. 

Amendments to the bill have been proposed, including SA 2848, SA 2850, and SA 2851, all of type SAMDT. Amendment SA 2848 was agreed to in the Senate by a 51–50 vote on July 1, 2025, with the stated purpose of "improving the bill." Amendments SA 2850 and SA 2851 were proposed on July 2, 2025, for similar reasons. The bill text was updated following H.Res. 492, indicating a revision to the House-passed version. 

No vote has occurred on H.R. 1 as of now, and no party-line or bipartisan vote is recorded. The bill is not currently in the legislative process and is widely regarded as a placeholder or symbolic effort, with no official status in Congress.

**Continuing Funding Passes Senate for 2026**

The Continuing Appropriations Act, 2026 (H.R. 5371) provides federal funding for agencies and programs in the 2026 fiscal year, maintaining operations at 2025 levels with limited flexibility and extending expiring programs. The bill was passed by the House and referred to the Appropriations and [Budget Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/house/hsbu00?format=json&api_key=SNIivcArmVb2FeWLaN6sHFBiE3J5HD2jLq569Wdd)s for review.  

Rep. Tom Cole (R-OK-4) is the sponsor of the legislation, with no cosponsors listed in the provided information. Although the bill is under consideration in the Senate, no cosponsors are identified as members of either the Appropriations or [Budget Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/house/hsbu00?format=json&api_key=SNIivcArmVb2FeWLaN6sHFBiE3J5HD2jLq569Wdd)s.  

A vote on the fourth cloture motion to proceed to consideration of the bill occurred in the Senate by a yeas-nays vote of 54–45. The motion to reconsider that vote was agreed to by voice vote. The record does not specify the partisan breakdown or whether the vote was bipartisan.  

No hearings have been held on the measure, and no amendments have been proposed. The Congressional Budget Office has issued cost estimates for the bill, with the latest update posted on September 16, 2025. The legislation is currently in the Senate, with procedural actions including a vote to proceed to consideration.

**Pay Troops During Shutdowns Amid Funding Uncertainty**

The Pay Our Troops Act of 2026 (H.R. 5401) provides for continued military and civilian pay during government shutdowns, covering active-duty service members, reserve personnel, and Department of Defense and Homeland Security civilian employees and contractors. The bill ensures pay continues until the earlier of the enactment of full-year appropriations or the end of the shutdown period.

Introduced in the U.S. House, the legislation was referred to the House Committee on Appropriations, where it is currently under review. Rep. Jennifer A. Kiggans (R-VA-2) serves as the bill’s sponsor, with additional cosponsors including Rep. Brian K. Fitzpatrick (R-PA-1), Rep. Nancy Mace (R-SC-1), and others from both parties. The bill has not yet undergone a hearing or received any proposed amendments, according to available records.

As of the latest information, no votes have occurred on H.R. 5401, and no official findings or committee reports have been documented. The bill is not currently before the full House, and its progress remains at the committee referral stage. The Congressional Record confirms that the bill was introduced on September 16, 2025, and is authorized under Article I, Section 8 of the U.S. Constitution.

bill_title: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2026
article_content:
**Senate Passes Military Construction Funding for 2026**

The Senate passed the Military Construction Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2026, also known as the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2026, on October 9, 2025, by a vote of 77–20. The vote, recorded as Record Vote Number 570, met the 60-vote threshold required for passage under Senate rules and included bipartisan support.  

The bill, sponsored by Sen. Roger F. Wicker [R-MS], is currently under consideration in the Senate [Armed Services Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/senate/ssas00?format=json&api_key=SNIivcArmVb2FeWLaN6sHFBiE3J5HD2jLq569Wdd). No cosponsors are listed, and no information is available to confirm any cosponsors’ committee membership.  

Amendments to the bill have been proposed, including SAMDT-type amendments SA 3925, SA 3928, and SA 3929. Amendment SA 3928, proposed by the Senate, directs the Secretary of Defense to establish a pilot program for deploying microreactors and was approved by voice vote on October 9, 2025. Details on the purposes and proposers of amendments SA 3925 and SA 3929 are not provided in the available context.  

No hearings were reported on the bill, and no findings from such proceedings are available. The bill authorizes funding for military construction activities and related programs for fiscal year 2026. A cost estimate for direct spending changes under the bill was issued by the Congressional Budget Office on September 3, 2025.  

The legislation is part of the broader National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2026 and is related to bills S2259, S2604, and S2601.

bill_title: A bill to designate the facility of the United States Postal Service located at 154 First Avenue East in Jerome, Idaho, as the "Representative Maxine Bell Post Office".
article_content:
**Senate Bill S.24 Designates Post Office in Idaho**

Senate Bill S.24 designates the U.S. Postal Service facility at 154 First Avenue East in Jerome, Idaho, as the "Representative Maxine Bell Post Office." The bill was introduced in the Senate by Senator Mike Crapo (R-ID) and cosponsored by Senator James E. Risch (R-ID).  

The legislation is currently in the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs, a chamber where both sponsors serve. As of the latest records, the bill has been read twice and referred to the committee, but no hearings have been held, and no findings or amendments have been proposed.  

No votes have occurred on the bill, and public records do not indicate any official vote results. The bill remains in the early stages of consideration, with no indication of whether the vote, if held, would have been party-line or bipartisan.

bill_title: Continuing Appropriations and Extensions and Other Matters Act, 2026
article_content:
**Senate Passes Continuing Appropriations Bill for 2026**

Senate Bill S.2882, titled the Continuing Appropriations and Extensions and Other Matters Act, 2026, provides continuing appropriations for federal agencies through the earlier of October 31, 2025, or the enactment of the applicable appropriations act. The measure prevents a government shutdown by funding operations during the transition period before FY2026 appropriations are finalized.

The bill was introduced in the Senate by Senator Patty Murray of Washington and is currently on the Senate Calendar. It includes provisions to permanently extend the expanded premium tax credit for health insurance, provide additional funding for Medicaid, and extend various expiring federal programs. No cosponsors are listed, and no amendments have been proposed.

Votes on the bill have occurred, including a second and third cloture motion on the motion to proceed, neither of which was invoked by a yea-nay vote. A voice vote approved a motion to proceed to reconsider the vote by which the second cloture was not invoked. Additionally, a motion by Senator Schumer to reconsider the vote by which the third cloture was not invoked was agreed to by voice vote. The partisan breakdown of these votes is not specified in the available records.

bill_title: Impeaching Donald John Trump, President of the United States, for high crimes and misdemeanors.
article_content:
**Support for AG Confirmation Process Expresses Constitutional Concerns**

House Resolution 353, introduced by Rep. Shri Thanedar (D-MI-13), expresses support for the appointment of a U.S. Attorney General and calls for confirmation proceedings to adhere to constitutional and legal standards. The resolution, which has no substantive policy or funding provisions, is a procedural measure designed to emphasize the importance of due process in the appointment process.

The bill was introduced in the 119th Congress and referred to the House Committee on the Judiciary for initial review. As of the latest update, no hearings have been held, and no amendments have been proposed. The resolution has not advanced beyond committee referral and no votes have occurred.

Cosponsors include Rep. Kweisi Mfume (D-MD-7), Rep. Jerrold Nadler (D-NY-12), Rep. Robin L. Kelly (D-IL-2), Rep. Janice D. Schakowsky (D-IL-9), and Rep. Al Green (D-TX-9). Rep. Schakowsky, a member of the [Judiciary Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/house/hsju00?format=json&api_key=SNIivcArmVb2FeWLaN6sHFBiE3J5HD2jLq569Wdd), is part of the committee overseeing the resolution’s consideration. The bill remains in the early stages of review with no public records indicating further action.

**Senate Passes Bill to Prevent Government Shutdowns**

Senate Bill S.499, the Government Shutdown Prevention Act of 2025, was introduced by Senator Rand Paul (R-KY) and referred to the Senate Committee on Appropriations. The bill would provide automatic continuing appropriations at 94% of the previous fiscal year’s funding level for an initial 90-day period to avoid a government shutdown. After that period, funding would be reduced by 1% every subsequent 90 days until regular appropriations legislation is passed.

The bill has been read twice and referred to the Committee on Appropriations. No cosponsors are listed in the available information. No hearings have been held on the measure, and no amendments or votes have occurred as of the latest data. The bill is currently under consideration by the Senate [Appropriations Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/senate/ssap00?format=json&api_key=SNIivcArmVb2FeWLaN6sHFBiE3J5HD2jLq569Wdd).

bill_title: An executive resolution authorizing the en bloc consideration in Executive Session of certain nominations on the Executive Calendar.
article_content:
**Senate Passes S.412 on Legislative Procedure**

Senate Resolution 412, introduced by Sen. John Thune (R-SD), addresses legislative rules and procedure in the Senate. The bill, which has no cosponsors, was considered and passed by unanimous consent agreement on October 3, 2025, with a yea-nay vote of 51–46 (Record Vote Number: 541).  

No committee action or hearings were held on the measure. The bill has not been referred to any committee, and no committee members are listed as having participated.  

Two amendments of type "SAMDT" were filed during the 119th Congress, but the context does not specify their authors or substantive content. The resolution was passed without amendment, indicating no changes were made during the vote.  

The bill's text is available in JSON format via the official Congress.gov API. No summary or findings are provided in the available context.

bill_title: Full-Year Continuing Appropriations and Extensions Act, 2025
article_content:
**Full-Year Funding Averted with Continuing Appropriations Act**

The Full-Year Continuing Appropriations and Extensions Act, 2025 (H.R. 1968), provides full-year funding for federal agencies and extends expiring authorities to prevent a government shutdown. Sponsored by Representative Tom Cole (R-OK-4), the bill has been referred to both the House [Budget Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/house/hsbu00?format=json&api_key=SNIivcArmVb2FeWLaN6sHFBiE3J5HD2jLq569Wdd) and the House [Appropriations Committee](https://api.congress.gov/v3/committee/house/hsap00?format=json&api_key=SNIivcArmVb2FeWLaN6sHFBiE3J5HD2jLq569Wdd) for review. 

No cosponsors are listed for the legislation, with the official record showing "Cosponsors: []." As a result, no cosponsors are affiliated with either committee. The bill has not been enacted into law, and no Public Law number (119-4) is officially assigned in current legislative records, though it is referenced in the Congressional Record as H.Res. 211. 

A procedural amendment, HAMDT 8, proposed by Representative Cole, was adopted on March 11, 2025, and relates to the approval of a Rules amendment (A001). This amendment does not alter the bill’s substantive provisions. Several SAMDT amendments (e.g., SAMDT 1284, 1285, 1287, 1288) were also introduced during the legislative process, though specific details remain unavailable. 

No hearings have been reported on H.R. 1968. Voting records, including party-line or bipartisan breakdowns, are not available in the provided context. The bill became Public Law No. 119-4 following procedural approval, though the official enactment status remains unconfirmed in public records.
